web.title: The Source
web.line: You can download the source from here. This page gives you links to look at it on the web. If you are not a programmer then you are probably best find something else to do. This is all computer stuff from here in. To get a head start into understanding all this lot there are a group of classes/documents in the docs package that contain only JavaDoc and no real code, that give an overview on some of the rest. (Effectively overview.html got too large and spilled out over here)
The JavaDoc was produced by a hacked up version of JavaDoc that generates links to the source, which is very useful. This hack is not of my invention - it comes from Sun's JavaDoc pages

There are several programs to the distribution:
ToolShed - a tool for converting Bible data and testing
B - and early desktop prototype, that is probably broken
BApplet - an applet demo
Servlets - Run on the web-server, generating content
Page - For viewing the Bible on the web
Web - For looking at basic web pages
Source - The source-code viewer
Config* - To configure the look of the other servlets

There are 2 ways of looking at the source.
The easy way is to read the JavaDoc
The hard way is to read the Source in the source servlet
The very hard way is to download the lot and compile it yourself
